title: 'Workers Over Billionaires' protests planned for Labor Day: See where in mid-Hudson
description: Protests aiming to 'unify working-class people' have been organized across the region for Labor Day.
content:
This Labor Day, New Yorkers are gearing up for another day of protests as several "Workers Over Billionaires" events are planned throughout the state.

The same organizers behind the May Day protests that took place across the country on May 1 are continuing their movement on Monday, Sept. 1.

"Labor and community are planning more than a barbecue on Labor Day this year because we have to stop the billionaire takeover," the website reads. "Just like any bad boss, the way we stop the takeover is with collective action."

Here's what to know about the latest protest.

'Workers Over Billionaires' protest planned for Monday: What are the protests about?

The "Workers Over Billionaires" movement is targeted to unify working-class people against billionaires who "are stealing from working families, destroying our democracy, and building private armies to attack our towns and cities," according to the website.

May Day Strong, the nationwide organization promoting the event, is calling for the following:
• None Stop the billionaire takeover and rampant corruption of the Trump administration.
• None Protect and defend Medicaid, Social Security and other programs for working people.
• None Fully funded schools, and healthcare and housing for all.
• None Stop the attacks on immigrants, Black, indigenous, trans people and all communities.

Is there a 'Workers Over Billionaires' Labor Day protest near me? See NY locations

There are protests planned in cities across the country, including 36 events in New York state, according to a map on the May Day Strong website. Here's where Workers Over Billionaires protests are planned throughout the state:

'Workers Over Billionaires' protests in the Hudson Valley region

This article originally appeared on Rochester Democrat and Chronicle: 'Workers Over Billionaires' protests planned across NY for Labor Day
summary: The same organizers behind the May Day protests that took place across the country on May 1 are planning several events throughout New York state on Labor Day. The "Workers Over Billionaires" movement aims to unite working-class people against billionaires who are profiting from working families, destroying democracy and attacking towns and cities. The nationwide organization promoting the event, May Day Strong, is calling for specific actions against these billionaires, including stopping the billionaire takeover and corruption within the Trump administration. There are protests planned in 36 cities across the nation, including 36 in New York State.
shortSummary: New York is set for a series of "Workers Over Billionaires" protests, focusing on uniting working families against billionaire takeover and privatization.

President Trump approval rating: Latest numbers show nine-point drop in one poll
President Donald Trump's approval rating has dropped to near-record lows, according to a national poll — the latest in a series of surveys released this month. The Pew Research Center poll, released Aug. 14, shows Trump with a 38% approval rating, down nine points since Pew’s February survey at the start of his second term. Sixty percent of respondents said they disapprove of his job performance. Pew attributes the decline to falling support from his 2024 voters and adults who didn’t vote in November.
Other recent polls show less dramatic shifts. For example, The Economist’s latest poll shows a slight increase in approval, suggesting mixed public sentiment.
Here’s how Trump’s approval ratings stack up across several national polls:
The Economist
Trump approval rating, according to the latest from The Economist (Aug. 15, 2025):
- Favorable: 42%
- Unfavorable: 54%
- Not sure: 4%
The latest report shows that voters believe the top three most important issues Americans are facing are inflation/prices, jobs and the economy, followed by health care. This ranking has remained steady in the past few months.
Morning Consult
Trump approval rating, according to the latest Morning Consult poll (Aug. 15, 2025):
- Favorable: 45%
- Unfavorable: 51%
Silver Bulletin
Trump approval rating according to Pollster Nate Silver's “Silver Bulletin” newsletter (Aug. 15, 2025):
- Favorable: 44%
- Unfavorable: 53%
Rasmussen
Trump approval rating, according to the latest Rasmussen poll (Aug. 15, 2025):
- Favorable: 49%
- Unfavorable: 49%
The figures include 33% of U.S. voters who "strongly approve" of the job Trump is doing as president as well as 40% of voters who "strongly disapprove," according to the report.
New York Times
Trump approval rating, according to the latest New York Times poll (Aug. 15, 2025):
- Favorable: 44%
- Unfavorable: 53%
Pew Research Center
Trump approval rating, according to Pew Research Center. (Aug. 14, 2025)
- Favorable: 38%
- Unfavorable: 60%

Trump approval rating, according to the latest from Quantus Insights poll (Aug. 14, 2025):
- Favorable: 47%
- Unfavorable: 49%
- Not sure: 4%
CNBC
Trump approval rating, according to CNBC (Aug. 7, 2025):
- Favorable: 47%
- Unfavorable: 51%
Real Clear Politics
Trump approval rating, according to the latest Real Clear Politics poll (July 28, 2025):
- Favorable: 46%
- Unfavorable: 52%
Reuters/Ipsos
Trump approval rating, according to the latest Reuters/Ipsos poll (July 25-27, 2025):
- Favorable: 40%
- Unfavorable: 56%
Navigator Research
Trump approval rating, specifically regarding the public's perception of President Trump, according to the latest Navigator Research poll (July 25, 2025):
- Favorable: 43%
- Unfavorable: 54%
Emerson College
Trump approval rating, according to the latest Emerson College poll (July 25, 2025):
- Favorable: 46%
- Unfavorable: 47%
Gallup
Trump approval rating, according to the latest Gallup poll (July 7-21, 2025):
- Favorable: 37%
- Unfavorable: 59%
- No opinion: 4%

- Unfavorable: 54%
Note: Polls are constantly changing and different pollsters ask different varieties of the population. These numbers were reflected as of Wednesday, Aug. 15, 2025, at 11 a.m.
President approval ratings: What they measure
A president’s approval rating reflects the percentage of Americans polled who approve of the president’s performance. Anything can impact a president's rating, such as legislation passed, actions and elections. According to ABC News, an approval rating doesn't just represent how well the administration is faring for the general public but could factor into the outcome of an upcoming election or how much they accomplish while in office.
Presidential approval ratings were first conducted by the founder of the American Institute of Public Opinion, George Gallup, around 1935 to gauge public support for the president of the United States during their term. While Gallup has tracked presidential approval for 70 years, other organizations also conduct and release their own polls. Among them, Ipsos and Morning Consult.
How does Trump's approval rating compare to previous presidents?
- Joe Biden (June 2021) - 56% approve
- Donald Trump (June 2017) - 38% approve
- Barack Obama (June 2009) - 61% approve
- George W. Bush (June 2001) - 54% approve
- Bill Clinton (June 1993) - 41% approve
- George H.W. Bush (June 1989) - 70% approve
- Ronald Reagan (June 1981) - 59% approve
- Jimmy Carter (June 1977) - 63% approve
- Richard Nixon (June 1969) - 63% approve
- John F. Kennedy (June 1961) - 73% approve

argos_summary: Workers Over Billionaires, a coalition led by May Day Strong, is staging 36 Labor Day protests across New York state to oppose billionaire influence and demand stronger social programs. The movement calls for ending corruption, protecting Medicaid, Social Security, schools, healthcare, housing, and safeguarding marginalized communities. Events run from noon to 6 p.m. in cities from Hudson Valley to Yonkers, with a broader national campaign that saw over 1,000 actions nationwide. The protests come amid a sharp decline in President Trump’s approval rating, which fell to 38 % in recent polls.
